titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Philip Agee Papers TAM.517
titlestmt.author: Aniko Szucs and Peter Filardo

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-06-27 18:24:28 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 19 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, 1 photograph box, 1 oversize flat box, 1 folder, and 2 Microsoft Word files.

did.abstract: Philip Burnett Franklin Agee (1935–2008) was a Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) case officer and writer, best known as the author of Inside the Company: CIA Diary (1975), which identifed about 250 CIA officers, front companies and foreign agents then or previously working for the United States. Agee joined the CIA in 1957, and over the following decade had postings in Washington, D.C., Ecuador, Uruguay, and Mexico. After resigning from the Agency in 1968, he became a leading opponent of CIA practices. Exiled from the U.S., and expelled from Great Britain, he died in Cuba in January 2008. The collection contains: biographical materials, correspondence, datebooks, documents obtained under the FOIA Act, notably CIA documents, as well as FBI and State Department documents; legal materials from various cases in which Agee was the plaintiff; lectures and university teaching files; subject files, many relating to Latin American and other countries and to CIA activity in them, and some relating to his expulsion from Great Britain; published and unpublished writings by Agee; reviews of his work; and other writings about Agee.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in mostly in English, with some materials in Spanish, and a small amount of materials in German, and other (principally European) languages.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Giselle Roberge Agee in 2009. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 2009.081 and 2011.064.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Philip Burnett Franklin Agee (July 19, 1935–January 7, 2008) was a United States Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) case officer and writer. He is best known as the author of Inside the Company: CIA Diary (1975), first published in Britain because of legal problems in the U.S., which identifed about 250 officers, front companies and foreign agents working for or cooperating with the United States. Agee joined the CIA in 1957, and over the following decade had postings in Washington, D.C., Ecuador, Uruguay, and Mexico. After resigning from the Agency in 1968, he became a leading opponent of CIA practices. Agee also wrote Dirty Work: The CIA in Western Europe (1978), Dirty Work: The CIA in Africa (1979), and a biography, On the Run (1987). Agee's work inspired the founding of the Covert Action Information Bulletin, for which he also wrote. He was exiled from the U.S., for revealing classified information, via the revocation of his passport by the U.S. Department of State in 1979 while he was abroad (upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1989). He was also pressured to leave Great Britain in 1977. He lectured throughout Western and Eastern Europe. Agee was also eventually expelled from Holland, France, West Germany, and Italy, and died in Cuba in January, 2008.

Agee was involved in several legal cases. Agee sued the United States Central Intelligence Agency, Federal Bureau of Investigation, National Security Agency, Department of State, and Department of Justice, seeking to obtain government documents under the Freedom of Information Act, and obtained numerous documents as a result of these complex legal proceedings that related to his former CIA employment, and to his investigative and writing activities. Agee also sued Barbara Bush,alleging that, in her Barbara Bush: Memoir (Scribner, 1994) she had falsely held him responsible for the death of Athens CIA Station Chief Richard Welch, assassinated in 1975. Agee also sued George Crile, Gust Avrakotos, Grove/Atlantic, the Atlantic Monthly Press, and Publishers Group West, claiming that Crile's book Charlie Wilson's War (Grove/Atlantic, 2003) falsely held him responsible for the death of Richard Welch.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Phillip Agee Papers; TAM 517; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The order of the series, and their contents was for the most part imposed on the loosely or apparently unorganized original materials.

Photographs were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the Phillip Agee Photographs (PHOTOS 284). In 2014, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the Phillip Agee Papers.
Floppy disks were forensically imaged and analyzed. Microsoft Word documents from these images were migrated to .pdf format for access, and Apache OpenOffice .odt files were created for preservation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains: biographical materials, photographs, correspondence, detailed datebooks; (U.S.) government documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) -- principally CIA documents, as well as FBI and State Department documents; legal materials from various cases in which Agee was the plaintiff; lectures and university teaching files in both paper and electronic format; subject files, many relating to Latin American and other countries and to the CIA's activities in relation to them, and some relating to his expulsion from Great Britain; writings by and about Agee; with clippings and clippings files throughout. The leading correspondent is Agee's attorney, Meliv L. Wulf; there is also correspondence with several publishers, with Noam Chomsky, Maurice Bishop, (revolutionary Prime Minister of Grenada from 1979-1983), Ilona Maria Lorenz (Fidel Castro's onetime lover, later hired by CIA to assassinate Castro), and publisher Lyle Stuart. The collection, in addition to documenting Agee's life, his career as a CIA agent and his subsequent activities to expose and oppose U.S. foreign intelligence activities and foreign policy goals, and legal cases in which he was involved, will also be of interest to the study of U.S. foreign intelligence activities and foreign policy, notably in relation to Latin America but also in Western Europe and elsewhere.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: In subseries VI-C, researchers must use the folder containing the copies of the fragile original clippings.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Phillip Agee were transferred to New York University in 2009 by Giselle Roberge-Agee. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series I, Biographical and Memorabilia (1975-1987) includes, in addition to Agee's typewriter (which was bugged by the CIA, and for which permisssion is required to view), includes the certificate of his marriage to Gysele Ingool, biographical profiles, business cards, certificates, clippings, itineraries and travel request forms, two plaques, and other memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series II, Correspondence (1954-2006) is organized into three subseries: the alphabetical correspondence includes correspondence with his attorney and writing collaborator Melvin Wulf, various periodicals and publishers, including Lyle Stuart, Maurice Bishop (Prime Minister of Grenada (1979-83), the Social Democratic Party of Germany and its youth organization, Noam Chomsky and various progressive activists and authors around the world; the chronological correspondence subseries contain single or at most a few letters from diverse individuals of lesser reknown, ; and the foreign languages subseries contains correspondence, in German and to a lesser degree, Spanish, and concerns Agee's literary and political activities and connections. Note that Melvin Wulf also sometimes appears as a correspondent or author in series IV, Government Documents, and V, Legal Cases and Documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series III, Datebooks (1975-2007) contains bound volumes containing both appointments and notes, some detailed. The datebooks combine features of ddate/appointment books with those of diaries and notebooks. Included is contextual information and notes about appointments, research notes and political ccommentary, sometimes commingled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Government Documents (1950-1989), contains materials obtained under the Freedom of Information Act, the largest number from the CIA, but also including documents from the Department of State (individual files on countries around the world, including several on Great Britain), the Department of Justice, and the FBI, and several small files from other agencies. The CIA files and Department of Justice files include, in addition to files requested by Agee about various activities of these agencies, also include files about Agee, and about the contested nature of the FOIA process. The FBI files are principally lists of deleted materials, i.e., materials not released, but there is also a list of released documents and well as some documents themselves.

Series V, Legal Cases and Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series V, Legal Cases and Documents, documents five lawsuits in which Agee was the plaintiff, and also contains a selection of legal documents from and correspondence with Agee's attornerys regarding other cases that were of interest to Agee. The majority of the series consists of affadavits and other legal documents from Agee's suit v. the United States Central Intelligence Agency, Federal Bureau of Investigation, National Security Agency, Department of State, and Department of Justice, seeking to obtain government documents under the Freedom of Information Act. There are a small number of files, chiefly legal correspondence, but with some legal documents, from two lawsuits in which Agee sought damages for allegedly being falsely accused of being responsible for the 1975 death of Athens, Greece CIA Station Chief Richard Welch. In this regard, Agee separately sued former First Lady Barbara Bush, charging that her Barbara Bush: A Memoir (1994) falsely made this claim. Agee also sued author George Crile, et al, on the same grounds re his book Charlie Wilson's War (Grove/Atlantic, 2003). Bush agreed to alter one paragraph in her book as per a 1997 settlement. For the Crile case a similar settlement was reached in 2004. From Agee's unsuccessful attempt to regain his passport by suing the Department of State are several files of clippings, correspondence, and legal documents. There is also one file of plaintiff's affadavits from the case Philip Agee v. United States of America: Civil Action No. 94-2020-WBB, To Recover Damages for Illegal and Tortious Acts Committed against the Plaintiff by the CIA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents the case between Barbara Bush and Agee who accused her of falsely accusing Agee, in Barbara Bush: A Memoir (Scribner, 1994), of being responsible for the death of Richard Welch CIA Athens Station Chief, killed in 1975 by the Greek Terrorist group November 17)

processinfo.p: The folder titles were largely taken from those assigned by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series VI, Subject Files (1950-2006) contains research files on countries, compiled by Agee, with a concentration on Latin America, and in paraticular Cuba and Nicaragua; files on individuals, organizations and topics, in particular sets of files on Aldrich Hazen Ames (1941- , a former CIA counter-intelligence officer and analyst, who, in 1994, was convicted of spying for the Soviet Union and Russia, which included revealing the names of CIA agents), and on Project Democracy, a Reagan-era foreign policy initiative; and files, including some legal documents on Agee's unsuccessful struggles against his expulsion, respectively, from Great Britain and the Netherlands. This series contains a broad range of printed ephemera, clippings files, speeches, internal documents of various organizations, and some letters.

Series VII, University Lectures, Teaching and Research Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series VII, University Lectures, Teaching and Research Files (1948-1999) contains lectures and resarch materials for his talks and courses in both paper and electronic format. Topics include U.S. foreign intelligence activity, the extreme right in Europe, including the activities of former Nazis in Germany, and files on a course "Reinhard Gehlen (a Nazi who collaborated with U.S. intelligence agencies) and the Continuation of the German War against the USSR." Agee taught most frequently in Europe, and within Europe, in both West and East Germany, and some of the materials are in German.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series VIII, Writings (1974-2007) includes published writings, including "Phillip Agee's Peregrinations-His Account," "Gulf War Launches New World Order," and book reviews; unpublished Writings, including the book-length "The CIA for Beginners: 100 Questions and Answers," and "The Blond Who Spied on Me"; interviews with Agee (press, radio, documentary); speeches, including several on Latin America; reviews of Agee's writings; writings about Agee; and writings by others that were of interest to Agee.

Series IX, Oversized Clippings About Agee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series IX, Oversized Clippings About Agee (1975-1980), contains clippings about Agee, or for events or activities involving Agee, some freestanding, some within issues of various newspapers and periodicals. Some of these are of graphic interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series X, Audiocassettes (undated) contains twelve audiocassettes from an untitled and undated seminar on various aspects of U.S. Intelligence activities, probably given in Europe, possibly in Germany, in the late 1990s or early 2000s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of Agee at speaking events, interviews, and other events. There are a significant amount of photographs from the Agee and Hosenball demonstrations. In 1977, Agee and Mark Hosenball, a journalist, were deported from the United Kingdom for revealing state secrets.

Other subjects of the photographs include Phillip Noel-Baker, Prime Minister of Grenada Maurice Bishop, Regina Fischer, Jo Richardson, Governor of California Jerry Brown, Fidel Castro, Ricardo Alarcón and others.
Most of the photographs were taken by Andrew Wiard.
